items.title: Inverted thumbnail ratio with orientation in source, ImageMagick (convert) engine
items.body:
Hello,

When a file needing a orientation change is made into a thumbnail, the aspect ratio is not inverted during the `-scale` operation. Leading to a distorsion in the result.

## Scenario

* source image (orientation `6`, size `1800x1200`). 1200 being the height of the not re-oriented source image and the width of the intermediate (`1200x1800`) re-oriented image: 
![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67459/73443334-c33c9f80-4356-11ea-9f93-f8f2033e2df2.jpg)
* `get_thumbnail(source_img, 600)`. Which should result, taking the orientation into account, to a `600x900` full geometry
* the convert command is actually called with `convert sourcefile -auto-orient -colorspace RGB -scale 600x400! -interlace line -quality 95 thumbfile`
* leading to the final image : ![69b40b75d5bcc7f77bb0b73b08bd3f83](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67459/73448313-d5bbd680-4360-11ea-91f9-c558984c528b.jpg)

## Additional note
* the dimensions seem to be reversed during a *set_size* but not at scale operation time
  * https://github.com/jazzband/sorl-thumbnail/blob/571388bbf079fa8671b5b54bee2a5bff933c2daa/sorl/thumbnail/images.py#L139-L145
  * https://github.com/jazzband/sorl-thumbnail/blob/571388bbf079fa8671b5b54bee2a5bff933c2daa/sorl/thumbnail/engines/base.py#L49-L54
* I haven't been able to check for the other engines
* most probably related to the first problem of #495

items.title: Exceptions when users upload a GIF
items.body:
Hi,

We are using `sorl-thumbnail==12.5.0` in [Speedy Net](https://github.com/speedy-net/speedy-net). I found out that an exception is raised when users upload an animated GIF to the server. The exception is raised when viewing the user's profile, which uses `sorl-thumbnail` to try to create a thumbnail. I submitted an [issue](https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/issues/4235) on `python-pillow/Pillow` but I understand now the bug might be in `sorl-thumbnail`. I received an exception - `OSError` - `cannot write mode RGBA as JPEG` - in `env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/PIL/JpegImagePlugin.py in _save, line 621`. Is there a way to fix this bug?

The errors come from `env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sorl/thumbnail/templatetags/thumbnail.py` when using the `thumbnail` template tag.

Another problem is that some images (see example below) display a thumbnail in some circumstances, but the thumbnail is empty in some circumstances (maybe depending on size) and therefore there is no thumbnail for a user who uploaded these images in some pages on Speedy Net, and he appears as a user who didn't upload a profile picture at all.

Thanks,
אורי.

items.title: Removal of query args break functionality
items.body:
I have a problem with how sorl-thumbnail removes query args from URL:s.

images.py:
```
        # Remove query args from names. Fixes cache and signature arguments
        # from third party services, like Amazon S3 and signature args.
        self.name = self.name.split('?')[0]
```

This might be great for S3-servers, but really bad for others. One example is a site that adds **?format=jpg** to image urls, and returns a 404 if you remove that. That will not work with this code.

It would be great if this could be made an option in sorl-thumbnail, possibly with the option to add a list of patterns for servers where args should be removed.

items.title: (Cached) thumbnail too slow (1s/thumbnail)
items.body: I'm working with the latest version of sorl-thumbnail (12.4a1) in a distributed system and the rendering is way too slow, around 1s/thumbnail. ##### Software used - sorl-thumbnail 12.4a1 - Python 3.5 - Django 1.11.3 - Google Cloud Storage - Redis 4.0 (through a Unix socket) - Ubuntu 17.04 (GNU/Linux 4.10.0-32-generic x86_64). ##### Expected behavior The thumbnail rendering should be practically instantaneous if cached. ##### Actual behavior The thumbnail rendering when cached takes around 1 second _(0.5-1.5s)_. ##### Steps to reproduce the behavior ``` {% thumbnail user.image.image as img %} {% empty %} {% endthumbnail %} ``` ##### Additional info I've identified a few problems: **1) Line 153: `output = self.nodelist_file.render(context)` takes ~1 second to render** ``` Timer unit: 1e-06 s Total time: 0.604442 s File: /Users/[...]/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sorl/thumbnail/templatetags/thumbnail.py Function: _render at line 129 Line # Hits Time Per Hit % Time Line Contents ============================================================== 129 @profile_each_line 130 def _render(self, context): 131 1 53 53.0 0.0 file_ = self.file_.resolve(context) 132 1 6 6.0 0.0 geometry = self.geometry.resolve(context) 133 1 0 0.0 0.0 options = {} 134 3 3 1.0 0.0 for key, expr in self.options: 135 2 2 1.0 0.0 noresolve = {'True': True, 'False': False, 'None': None} 136 2 13 6.5 0.0 value = noresolve.get(text_type(expr), expr.resolve(context)) 137 2 2 1.0 0.0 if key == 'options': 138 options.update(value) 139 else: 140 2 2 1.0 0.0 options[key] = value 141 142 1 1832 1832.0 0.3 thumbnail = get_thumbnail(file_, geometry, **options) 143 144 1 2 2.0 0.0 if not thumbnail or (isinstance(thumbnail, DummyImageFile) and self.nodelist_empty): 145 if self.nodelist_empty: 146 return self.nodelist_empty.render(context) 147 else: 148 return '' 149 150 1 2 2.0 0.0 if self.as_var: 151 1 9 9.0 0.0 context.push() 152 1 3 3.0 0.0 context[self.as_var] = thumbnail 153 1 602506 602506.0 99.7 output = self.nodelist_file.render(context) 154 1 6 6.0 0.0 context.pop() 155 else: 156 output = thumbnail.url 157 158 1 1 1.0 0.0 return output ``` **2) The class `ImageFile(BaseImageFile)` from sorl.thumbnail.images takes between 0.5-1 second if used with Google Cloud Storage from _django-storages_ due to the methods of `self.storage`** This lag is especially noticeable in this section of the previously mentioned class: ``` if hasattr(self.storage, 'location'): location = self.storage.location if not self.storage.location.endswith("/"): location += "/" if self.name.startswith(location): self.name = self.name[len(location):] ``` ##### HINT: I think many of the performance problems could be related to the function `url` of ImageFile(BaseImageFile) because the APIs of cloud storages can be a bit tricky. ``` Timer unit: 1e-06 s Total time: 0.832383 s File: /Users/[...]/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sorl/thumbnail/images.py Function: url at line 159 Line # Hits Time Per Hit % Time Line Contents ============================================================== 159 @property 160 @profile_each_line 161 def url(self): 162 1 832383 832383.0 100.0 return self.storage.url(self.name) ```

items.title: Pillow 3.7 doesn't support RGBA as JPEG mode
items.body:
Hi!

Before Pillow 3.7 the code at PIL/JpegImagePlugin.py had a deprecation warning about using RGBA on a JPEG image and converted it to RGB.

```
if im.mode == 'RGBA':
    warnings.warn(
        'You are saving RGBA image as JPEG. The alpha channel will be '
        'discarded. This conversion is deprecated and will be disabled '
        'in Pillow 3.7. Please, convert the image to RGB explicitly.',
        DeprecationWarning
    )
```
As the comment says it has been deprecated since 3.7.

A way to solve it would be to modify pil_engine.py, overwritting colorspace (the wrapper) to forward the image format to _colorspace, and then converting it to RGB if it's a JPEG with RGBA

items.title: Add __str__() method to ImageFile
items.body:
While the documentation recommends using thumb.url in templates, there are circumstances where only the filename is needed; currently ImageFile only has a __unicode__() method, which gives the wrong results when used with Python 3 (since it falls back to the repr())
I think adding a __str__ method (possibly with Django's decorator) would help a lot - while using thumb.name is perfectly viable, the change in behavior risks breaking pages without any message.

items.title: Feature request: crop=contain
items.body:
It would be great if the template tag `{% thumbnail %}` could take an option similar to CSS's option `background-size: contain`.

For instance, it would be nice to be able to fit a square reddish image (60x60) into the destination image size (120x60) so that it would look like this:

![contain](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/355454/25893042/4b85d54a-356e-11e7-8a36-f25f12612c0e.png)

This would be useful for generating images for OpenGraph, for instance.

items.title: No module named PIL and No module named Image
items.body:
I'm use nginx+uwsgi+django 1.10+python3.5 on my virtual server. On my virtual server I installed last Pillow version - 4.1.1. 
On my local computer I use django server for **same project**.  On my local computer preinstalled Pillow 3.1.2. 
Also I use sorl-thumbnail 12.3 on both.

My local computer project perfect works. Without problems.

items.title: Add `sorl_thumbnail_tags` templatetag library that mirrors traditional `thumbnail`
items.body:
Add `sorl_thumbnail_tags` templatetag library that mirrors traditional `thumbnail`.

This allows usage of sorl-thumbnail in templates by {% load sorl_thumbnail_tags %} instead of traditional {% load thumbnail %}. It's specifically useful in projects that do make use of multiple thumbnailer libraries (for instance `easy-thumbnails` alongside `sorl-thumbnail`).

Works fine in my [fork](https://github.com/barseghyanartur/sorl-thumbnail/blob/master/sorl/thumbnail/templatetags/sorl_thumbnail_tags.py). If you, in principle, have nothing against addition of `sorl_thumbnail_tags` mirror, I'll add tests and update the documentation prior making a pull request.

items.title: Deprecated `TEMPLATE_DEBUG` setting is required by sorl-thumbnail
items.body:
The `TEMPLATE_DEBUG` setting which was deprecated in Django 1.8 and 1.9, and is missing from [1.10's docs](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.10/ref/settings/#template-debug) (so I assume it's now obsolete) is required by sorl-thumbnail.

Without a `TEMPLATE_DEBUG` setting I get this when I try and use the `{% thumbnail ... %}` tag in a template:

`'Settings' object has no attribute 'TEMPLATE_DEBUG'`

If I add it to my settings, the template tag works.

items.title: Proposal: Move to Jazzband to expand development efforts
items.body:
Quoting from the [Jazzband website](https://jazzband.co/)

> Jazzband is a cooperative experiment to reduce the stress of maintaining Open Source software alone.

We use this project in a few of our applications, and I can see that we're not the only ones using it. I've noticed the backlog of tickets and pull requests, as well as the long time since the latest release.

As a fellow open source maintainer, I understand the added work that goes into maintaining an open source project, especially one that isn't your main focus. That's why I'm proposing that you move (or donate, same idea) the project to Jazzband, to increase the number of possible maintainers of the project.

You can read more about how Jazzband works (and the guidelines for submitting projects) at https://jazzband.co/about/guidelines

items.title: convert_engine is broken in 12.4a1
items.body:
See https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/core/files/temp.py#L28

```
Note that unlike tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile from the standard library,
__init__() does not support the 'delete' keyword argument in
Python 2.6+, or the 'delete', 'buffering', 'encoding', or 'newline'
keyword arguments in Python 3.0+.
```

Your code uses the delete argument on line 71 see https://github.com/mariocesar/sorl-thumbnail/blob/3541db7f4160a126eecd8441348390955e5b7779/sorl/thumbnail/engines/convert_engine.py#L71.

Will break code with `__init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'delete'`.

Relates https://github.com/mariocesar/sorl-thumbnail/pull/392 and https://github.com/mariocesar/sorl-thumbnail/pull/358.

Why did tests pass?

items.title: Adding Django migrations will break migrations for people still using South
items.body:
South < 1.0 will try and use the Django migrations in the migrations dir.

South >= 1.0 will try south_migrations directory first and fall back to the migrations dir.

In both cases this will throw an ImportError ('Can't import django.db.migrations')

Off the top of my head - the best solution is probably to add a south_migrations directory (probably can be empty apart from **init**.py) and to document the fact that South >=1.0 is required. (I don't think it's advisable to put this in requirements.txt or setup.py as users should really be made aware of this instead of just upgrading it for them)

items.title: Cached DB misalignment when creating thumbnails with celery and usign default cache configuration
items.body:
Hi,
I have this thumbnail generation cycle:
- Upload an Image
- create one high-priority thumbnail in request-response cycle
- fire some celery tasks to create other resolution low-priority thumbnails

Creation works perfectly.
Deletion has a problem: when I delete the image I also call sorl.thumbnail.delete in order to delete thumbnails.
Only image and thumbnail generated in request-response cycle are deleted.
Other low-priority thubmnails are not deleted.

I investigated the problem and these are different tests:
- When I create all thumbnails in request-response cycle, deletion works great, all thumbnails are deleted
- When I create thumbnails by celery BUT i restart django development server BEFORE deleting image, all thumbnails are deleted. I interpret this as django reloads cache from DB, and now "sees" all thumbnails attached to image i'm deleting. 
  Note: I have reverted commit SHA: a5eef97 as I pointed out in #380 in order to get the DB correctly populated.

The very strange behaviour is this: 
If I dump cache content before deleting image from a management command, cache is populated correctly during all tests, I see all thumbnails associated to main image.
However during image deletion, cache seems misaligned, it contains ONLY the high priority thumbnail associated to main image.

I have put print statement inside _get_raw and _set_raw to dump call parameters.
For _set_raw I also added a cache.get() in order to dump the situation before setting cache.

items.title: Missing User-Agent header prevents thumbnailing of images behind CloudFlare
items.body: TLDNR `sorl.thumbnail` cannot make thumbnails when they are behind a CDN service like CloudFlare. The problem seems to be a missing `User-Agent` header. We have several Django sites in a colo. One site makes thumbnails from images hosted on another site in the same cluster. Everything worked fine until we started using CloudFlare. Requests for thumbnails hang, time out, and no thumbnails would be generated. Flipping CloudFlare development mode on and off makes no difference. Everything works properly if thumbnails are requested from the source via its LAN IP. This traceback comes from an email circa November 2014, when we first noticed the problem: ``` >>> from sorl.thumbnail import get_thumbnail >>> get_thumbnail(u'http://ddr.densho.org/media/ddr-densho-35/ddr-densho-35-428-mezzanine-8a1585375c-a.jpg', '100x100') Traceback (most recent call last): File "", line 1, in File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/sorl/thumbnail/shortcuts.py", line 8, in get_thumbnail return default.backend.get_thumbnail(file_, geometry_string, **options) File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/sorl/thumbnail/base.py", line 56, in get_thumbnail source_image = default.engine.get_image(source) File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/sorl/thumbnail/engines/convert_engine.py", line 53, in get_image fp.write(source.read()) File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/sorl/thumbnail/images.py", line 121, in read return self.storage.open(self.name).read() File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/sorl/thumbnail/images.py", line 169, in open return urllib2.urlopen(name) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 127, in urlopen return _opener.open(url, data, timeout) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 407, in open response = meth(req, response) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 520, in http_response 'http', request, response, code, msg, hdrs) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 445, in error return self._call_chain(*args) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 379, in _call_chain result = func(*args) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 528, in http_error_default raise HTTPError(req.get_full_url(), code, msg, hdrs, fp) HTTPError: HTTP Error 403: Forbidden ``` As of version 12.2 `get_thumbnail` fails silently: ``` >>> from sorl.thumbnail import get_thumbnail >>> t1 = get_thumbnail( 'http://ddr.densho.org/media/ddr-densho-35/ddr-densho-35-428-mezzanine-8a1585375c-a.jpg', '100x100' ) >>> t1.exists() False >>> t2 = get_thumbnail( 'http://10.0.2.123/media/ddr-densho-35/ddr-densho-35-428-mezzanine-8a1585375c-a.jpg', '100x100' ) >>> t2.exists() True ``` We worked around this by giving `sorl` image URLs with the internal IP rather than the domain name: ``` {% load thumbnail %} {% thumbnail img_src_local "100x100" as thumb %} {% endthumbnail %} ``` The problem seems to be a missing `User-Agent` header: ``` >>> import urllib2 >>> # Local IP >>> urllib2.urlopen( ... 'http://10.0.2.123/media/ddr-densho-35/ddr-densho-35-428-mezzanine-8a1585375c-a.jpg' ... ) > >>> # Domain name >>> urllib2.urlopen( ... 'http://ddr.densho.org/media/ddr-densho-35/ddr-densho-35-428-mezzanine-8a1585375c-a.jpg' ... ) Traceback (most recent call last): File "", line 2, in File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 154, in urlopen return opener.open(url, data, timeout) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 437, in open response = meth(req, response) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 550, in http_response 'http', request, response, code, msg, hdrs) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 475, in error return self._call_chain(*args) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 409, in _call_chain result = func(*args) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/urllib2.py", line 558, in http_error_default raise HTTPError(req.get_full_url(), code, msg, hdrs, fp) HTTPError: HTTP Error 403: Forbidden >>> # Domain name with User-Agent >>> req = urllib2.Request( ... 'http://ddr.densho.org/media/ddr-densho-35/ddr-densho-35-428-mezzanine-8a1585375c-a.jpg', ... headers={'User-Agent': "Django App"} ... ) >>> urllib2.urlopen(req) > ```

items.title: Test suite failure: pgmagick._pgmagick.get_blob_data raises UnicodeDecodeError in python 3.4
items.body:
Currently the test suite is failing on my machine for all py34-django*-pgmagick environments, because `pgmagick._pgmagick.get_blob_data` raises a `UnicodeDecodeError`.

I notice that the [import for `get_blob_data`](https://github.com/mariocesar/sorl-thumbnail/blob/5568c79fe29d011a876ef6e7453794079dc4f0aa/sorl/thumbnail/engines/pgmagick_engine.py#L7-L13) conditionally uses b64decode to import blob data instead, and it doesn't have this problem (swapping in the b64decode implementation works fine on all environments). 

Is pgmagick's implementation of `get_blob_data` used where available for performance reasons?  If so, and if it's worth it to keep that optimization, it may be necessary to also condition the implementation to use on the python version so that python>3 can be happy with the bytes returned by it.

items.title: Sorl-thumbnail is generating thumbnails in wrong size.
items.body:
I have an image here, i uploaded it to dropbox with same name at server:

https://www.dropbox.com/s/q2v8b7jrznyvh68/aaacc6460e2e4a0aa653fa8bbaa59f61?dl=0

The problem is, i'm getting thumbnail of this image with this command:

```
thmb = get_thumbnail(img, '220')
```

Expecting that thumbnail width will be 220, but...

```
> thmb.width
70
```

Original image size is 1836 × 3264 pixels. Size of thumbnail should be:

```
ratio = 220 / 1836 = 0.11982570806100218
(1836 * ratio)X(3264 * ratio) =  220X391 pixels.
```

But sorl-thumbnail is giving me 70x124 image. I followed source code of sorl-thumbnail and last line in this function looked suspicious for me:

```
# base.py:63
def _calculate_scaling_factor(self, x_image, y_image, geometry, options):
    crop = options['crop']
    factors = (geometry[0] / x_image, geometry[1] / y_image)
    return max(factors) if crop else min(factors)
```

If crop is not given,  function is returning "desired_thumbnail_height / y_image" then, new image width and height is calculated by multiplying source_image_width with factor. 

Am i missing something or this _calculate_scaling_factor method is behaving wrong. I think it must return geometry[0] / x_image if there is no height given.

items.title: Catching all IOErrors when getting images
items.body:
[`sorl.thumbnail.base.get_thumbnail()`](https://github.com/mariocesar/sorl-thumbnail/blob/master/sorl/thumbnail/base.py#L62) catches all `IOError`s and logs a rather unhelpful (in many cases) error `Remote file [%s] at [%s] does not exist`. 

There are many reasons why this function may fail (in my case `urlopen` was failing due to Python not picking up the SSL certificate store on FreeBSD).

It would be more helpful to catch the exception and use `logger.exception()` to give developers better insight into what's actually going on under the hood.

items.title: Serious performance issues in 12.2 (AWS S3)
items.body:
Hello,

There is a serious performance issue in current 12.2 branch. Problem is that we have ~2M thumbnails, so if execution goes here (marked line):

``` python
# /sorl/thumbnail/base.py:101 (get_thumbnail)
        # We have to check exists() because the Storage backend does not
        # overwrite in some implementations.
        if not thumbnail.exists(): # <---- This is the root of the problem!
            try:
                source_image = default.engine.get_image(source)
            except IOError:
                if settings.THUMBNAIL_DUMMY:
                    return DummyImageFile(geometry_string)
                else:
                    # if S3Storage says file doesn't exist remotely, don't try to
                    # create it and exit early.
                    # Will return working empty image type; 404'd image
                    logger.warn(text_type('Remote file [%s] at [%s] does not exist'),
                                file_, geometry_string)

                    return thumbnail

            # We might as well set the size since we have the image in memory
            image_info = default.engine.get_image_info(source_image)
            options['image_info'] = image_info
            size = default.engine.get_image_size(source_image)
            source.set_size(size)

            try:
                self._create_thumbnail(source_image, geometry_string, options,
                                       thumbnail)
                self._create_alternative_resolutions(source_image, geometry_string,
                                                     options, thumbnail.name)
            finally:
                default.engine.cleanup(source_image)
```

it is actually asks boto to return LIST of all stored thumbnails (without even using prefix), so appliction hangs with 100% CPU and high memory usage (well, not a surprise actually).

Wouldn't it be better to provide a prefix for lookup (constructed with the same function as used to store thumbnail) ? 

In a mean time we've had to revert to 11.12.1b which works better.

This is related to a fix introduced in #92

items.title: Division by zero on smart crop
items.body:
I'm getting a `float division by zero` error here:

```
sorl/thumbnail/engines/pil_engine.py in _get_image_entropy, line 239
```

I'm calling it using:

```
{% thumbnail comment.user.profile.avatar_image "30x30" crop="smart" as im %}
```

This happens on some images and not others. The image that's causing me issues is this one:

https://www.dropbox.com/s/m5e79cvk53ujs7b/Chelsea_physic_garden.jpg?dl=0

From a brief bit of digging the code is:

```
def _get_image_entropy(self, image):
    """calculate the entropy of an image"""
    hist = image.histogram()
    hist_size = sum(hist)
    print hist_size
    hist = [float(h) / hist_size for h in hist]
    return -sum([p * math.log(p, 2) for p in hist if p != 0])
```

`print hist_size` gives a zero in the console - hence the error. We need some sort of `try`/`except` on this calculation, but I'm not sure what the `except` should be!

items.title: More speed problems thumbnails from S3
items.body:
It's taking 1+ seconds per thumbnail for pages to load on their first hit, when image processing is occurring.

My problems sound very similar to those discussed in #252, with a few differences. I am pulling image sources directly from other sites, and using S3 to store and serve the processed thumbnails (that is, I am not using 3rd party key-value store, but the built-in DB solution). I might suspect this as a problem but had no performance issues of this magnitude before when the only difference was that I was serving the processed images locally rather than from the web server. 

Once I moved my `MEDIA_URL` to S3, using `boto` 2.34.0 and `django-storages` 1.1.8, it began taking about 1 second per thumbnail to load each page for the first time. Subsequent load times still seem a bit laggy but are many times faster than this. This is all with `django` 1.7. It doesn't seem possible for it to be this slow unless it is doing the work 100% in serial.

I have been using sorl-thumbnail==12.1c, but I also tried the version mentioned there as well as the latest 48d34d8612745fbb7c584f07a89f97c45adb67f9.  I opened this issue since the one in #252 was supposedly resolved by this point.  

It wouldn't surprise me if I'm doing something wrong. Thanks for the help.

items.title: If there is a connection error on S3, an empty thumbnail is created and cannot be deleted.
items.body:
I had to re-render all thumbnails on a live site (about 300). They are stored on S3. After the first 100 or so S3 started reporting connection errors. Which resulted in Sorl creating empty thumbnails for all remaining images. Those are written in the cache, so it's not going to check again. 
The images exist on S3, I checked.

On the website there are a lot of empty placeholders now where there should be images.

Checkout thumbnail/base.py, line 105.

items.title: Bug: Pillow validates file before the configured engine!
items.body:
When I try to upload a pdf file with GraphicsMagick engine (convert_engine), I get

`Upload a valid image. The file you uploaded was either not an image or a corrupted image.`

Which should not happen because Imagemagick and Graphicsmagick can handle it.

The bug is that the `class ImageFormField` 
https://github.com/mariocesar/sorl-thumbnail/blob/master/sorl/thumbnail/fields.py#L49

``` python
class ImageFormField(forms.ImageField):
     default_error_messages = {
        'invalid_image': _("Upload a valid image. The file you uploaded was "
                           "either not an image or a corrupted image."),
    }

    def to_python(self, data):
        """
        Checks that the file-upload field data contains a valid image (GIF,
        JPG, PNG, possibly others -- whatever the engine supports).
        """
        f = super(ImageFormField, self).to_python(data)
        if f is None:
            return None
```

inherits from Django's `forms.ImageField` 
https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/forms/fields.py#L634

and calls `django.forms.ImageField`'s  to_python at the beginning of the override and `django.forms.ImageField`  simply rejects pdf files in it's `to_python` method because Pillow can't open it!
https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/forms/fields.py#L663

``` python
        try:
            # load() could spot a truncated JPEG, but it loads the entire
            # image in memory, which is a DoS vector. See #3848 and #18520.
            image = Image.open(file)
            # verify() must be called immediately after the constructor.
            image.verify()

            # Annotating so subclasses can reuse it for their own validation
            f.image = image
            f.content_type = Image.MIME[image.format]
        except Exception:
            # Pillow doesn't recognize it as an image.
            six.reraise(ValidationError, ValidationError(
                self.error_messages['invalid_image'],
                code='invalid_image',
            ), sys.exc_info()[2])
```

**In essence, no matter what engine you configure for sorl, the file validation will happen with Pillow first and only if Pillow can deal with the file, will the actual configured engine get it**

The fix should be:

`class ImageFormField` should inherit directly from `django.forms.FileField` instead of `django.forms.ImageField`

i.e.

``` python
class ImageFormField(forms.FileField):
    ...
```

and let the configured engine figure out if it can deal with the file, directly.

**Note**: I do understand that sorl is all about Image thumbnails and might not be intended towards pdfs but since it can use Imagemagick/Graphicsmagick as engine and they can generate image thumbnails of pdfs, I think this a valid use case.

items.title: JPG thumbnails not being generated when serving website on a non-FQDN
items.body: This issue took a away a few hours of my life, so it's my duty to report it. That said, I'm still not sure what's exactly going on here (I'm more a front-end dev than a back-end one). So far, the project is pretty simple: a single web page, all content is hardcoded directly in the template, database is only used by sorl-thumbnail to store the key-values. Images are provided to the sorl-thumbnail tag as if they were external images (basically, I concatenate some strings to get the full URL for an image stored somewhere in the `/static/` folder). Like this: ``` {% with 'http://'|add:request.get_host|add:STATIC_URL|add:'website/images/someproduct.jpg' as source %} {% endwith %} ``` I'm developing locally, at my home, on a desktop/server running Debian Testing. First, let me say that when running the project using the Django development server on a virtualenv, sorl-thumbnail works flawlessly. It doesn't matter if the website is served at `http://localhost` or `http://project.localhost` or `http://project.localhost.lan` or even at `http://project.myhomeserver.com`. It just works. Problem arises when I try to "deploy" it. By "deploy", I just mean to create a copy of the website, running on the _same_ machine, but this copy now running as if it was a "production" copy. This means that I've set up a vhost in Apache (following the official documentation), and set `DEBUG` to `False`. So, my first try was to serve the website at `http://project-vhost.localhost`. Page loaded successfully (including static assets, like CSS and JS), but most sorl-thumbnail-related images were missing. Why "most"? This was the exception: any `sorl-thumbnail`'ed image in PNG format was processed (its thumbnails generated and cached in `/media/cache`) and served by Apache, as expected. But all JPG files were missing, the browser showing the classic frame of an image not loaded. When right-clicking the image and opening it on a new tab, the URL was one corresponding to a (sorl-thumbnail generated) thumbnail, like `http://project-vhost.localhost/media/cache/a7/1d/a71d9e08969c87f570aaddb4e03ce52b.jpg`, and Apache returned a 404 Not Found. Of course, I checked if the corresponding file existed at `/path/to/project/media/cache/a7/1d/a71d9e08969c87f570aaddb4e03ce52b.jpg`, and no, it wasn't there. My first guess was: "if PNG files are processed and JPG files aren't, then this issue is related with some OS image library and/or Pillow". So I reinstalled the OS libraries and reinstalled Pillow, but the problem remained. Then I tried installing [other image librares](http://sorl-thumbnail.readthedocs.org/en/latest/requirements.html#image-library), but no luck. By that time, I was really tired of tinkering, and, also, already run out of ideas The next morning, while connected to the Internet from outside of my home, I decided to do some remote work on my home server, to see if I could finally figure out what was going on. So I opened the browser and visited the website using its public URL: `http://project-vhost.myhomeserver.com`. And you know what? **All images loaded flawlessly**. So, after the WTF moment, and when I returned home, I tried again. These are the results: - Visiting `http://project-vhost.localhost` -> JPG images not generated and not served - Visiting `http://project-vhost.myhomeserver.com` -> JPG images generated, everything working as expected. - Visiting `http://project-vhost.localhost.lan` -> Idem. JPG images generated, everything working as expected. So, bottom line, my guess is: there seems to be an issue between sorl-thumbnail, images library and non-FQDN when doing a proper deploy of Django behind Apache. No issues when on Django development server. Can anyone try to reproduce this? Feel free to ask me for more info.

items.title: Caching is currently not working.

items.title: Django 1.7 Support Discussion
items.body:
Let me preface this by saying: I am aware that sorl does not claim to support django 1.7. However, I installed it anyway and would like to open a discussion around what I've found and find possible resolutions. 

Firstly, I've had moderate success. For the most part everything seems to work. However, it seems god awful slow when compared to running the same version of sorl on previous versions of django. I'm seeing a lot of CPU spikes and harikiri messages from uwsgi. Newrelic points me to sorl get_thumbnail as my biggest waste. 1 user (me) brought the server to a halt just checking that each page would load. Removing sorl fixes the issues.

My setup: I'm running postgres on a aws rds, 512Mb aws ec2 webserver, filesystem storage, and memcached for caching. Again, i'm leaning away from the server setup being the issue it handles load fine when sorl is removed.

items.title: Thumbnails recreated after ./mange.py thumbnail clear
items.body:
In the documentation is mentioned that a `./manage.py thumbnail clear` deletes all the entries in the key value storage but leaves the thumbnail files on the disk. If you hit the template tag again and the thumbnail file is still existing it is _not_ recreated.

This is not correct. 

If you hit the template tag and there is a thumbnail file for it a new file is created with the same name but a  prefix is added ("XXXX_1.jpg"). I think this is because Djangos default storage is used for creating thumbnails.

This happens with this version: sorl-thumbnail==11.12.1b

(I have millions of thumbnails and now I want to get rid of some formats to save disk space. So the behavior as stated in the documentation is exactly what I need)

items.title: Add support for overriding HTTP Auth prompt.
items.body:
Just had the confusing experience of deploying a simple site to staging, protected with HTTP Auth, and getting proxy timeouts on some pages. Running the Django development server shows an HTTP Auth prompt for those requests. Sorl is using FancyURLOpener to get a readable file from a URL, and by default it will prompt for HTTP Auth.

The answer was found here: https://docs.python.org/2/library/urllib.html#urllib._urlopener which appears to suggest monkey patching `urllib`. A note in the sorl docs for the `{% thumbnail %}` template tag where it mentions a `url` can be given as the source would have saved me a bunch of time.

Sorl could even go so far as to do this monkey patching (or conditionally do it) and allow users to set HTTP Auth credentials in their Django settings.

items.title: Django 1.4 no longer supported
items.body:
Commit 48e43806c9e95fed25c10796e3b6d3557eecaab5 makes use of `smart_text` which was introduced in Django 1.5.

This could be either solved by removing the mention of Django 1.4 in the `README` or reverting back to the use of `smart_str`.
